instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message:
No liquid damage.

Board only:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 13V (F7000/2)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.41V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?
Check the signals from power on sequence...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.31V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS_XXXXXXXX</SIGNAL> - you need readings from all lines? Is that correct?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message: Don't you think all are connected together???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message:
Yep, they are :D

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5G</SIGNAL> 0V (no short to ground)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message: So you have <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, or not?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5G</SIGNAL> - 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.31V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.
Be sure to use 61/87W charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message:
Genuine 87W charger and USB C cable.

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> - 3.30V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message: Yes, got pulse drop from 3.3V to 0.3V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message:
Check if <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals pulse at same time.
If yes, check for pulse on big coils too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> - 0V, no spike (all of them)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message:
Looks like PCH issue.
Check its RTC signals.

Also check <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - 3.40V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> - 1.98V

<SIGNAL>PP3V1_RTC</SIGNAL> - 3V
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.05V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.05V
<SIGNAL>PPDCPRTC_PSH</SIGNAL> - 1.16V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> - 1.98V"
Houston, we have a problem!

Force 330K instead of <RESISTOR>R1401</RESISTOR>.
If still lower than 2.4V, then heat PCH area with quality flux.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL>  - 2.45V

Issue still the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message: Still no pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message: no pulse

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V, 0A
threads.message: That points to PCH issue; heat it with quality flux...
